Expectation1: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation1: A delivery is expected this afternoon while I will be at home and the neighbor often misses packages.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: An emergency motion for a temporary restraining order has just been filed, requiring you to immediately review the documents and make a ruling within the hour.
Story: I was just settling into my study, stacks of case files spread before me, when my phone buzzed. It was my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, asking if I could receive a package for her this afternoon. She’s missed deliveries before, and I know how much she relies on me for these small favors. I glanced at the clock—her package was due any minute. At the same time, my clerk emailed: an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order had just been filed. I was expected to review the documents and make a ruling within the hour. The weight of my judicial responsibility pressed on me; someone’s safety could depend on my careful, immediate attention. Yet, I also felt the tug of neighborly duty, the unspoken expectation that we look out for each other. My mind raced, torn between the urgency of the law and the simple trust of a neighbor. I stood in the hallway, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once, and feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
